note.p: Education: Edinburgh; MA; Incorporated at Oxford (1694); Balliol College, Oxford. BMed, DMed (1713)

Career: Lecturer in Experimental Philosophy at Hart Hall, Oxford; Deputy to the Sedleian Professor of Natural Philosophy (1699); Treasurer of the Palatines (1709); took refugees from the Palatinate to New England, returning (1711); Decipherer to Queen Anne and George I (1712-1716); Savilian Professor of Astronomy at Oxford (1712-death); defended Newton against charges of plagiarism by Leibniz; died of a violent fever
Sources: Bulloch's Roll; DNB; DSB; Thomas; Eloy
References: H E Bell, 'The Savilian Professors' Houses and Halley's Observatory at Oxford' in NR 1961 vol 16 pp 179-186
Sir Alan Cook, 'The 350th Anniversary of the Birth of G W Leibniz, FRS' in NR 1996 vol 50 pp 153-163
J P Zinsser, 'The ultimate commentary: a consideration of I Bernhard Cohen's Guide to Newton's Principia' in NR 2003 vol 57 pp 231-238
Notes: According to Hunter, he was admitted in 1702.
